newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU plans for euro coins hit snag.
newsitem.headline: EU plans for euro coins hit snag.

text.p: The European Union's plans for new euro coins have hit a series of snags, forcing a high-level experts group to go back to the drawing board.

EU finance ministers have told the group -- made up of senior officials from national mints across the 15-nation bloc -- to reconsider both the shape of one of the proposed new coins and the metal content of two others.
Euro coins are due to enter circulation in 2002 in countries participating in the EU's economic and monetary union (EMU).

Designs for the coins are currently being presented to a jury. The winning designs are expected to be unveiled at a summit of EU leaders in Amsterdam in June. The designs for notes were shown to EU leaders in Dublin in December.
The experts group has been dealing with the technical aspects of the coins, such as their shape, size and metal content.
EU officials said one of the main snags had arisen with the planned half-euro coin, the value of which against other currencies will not be known until 1999.
In order to help blind consumers differentiate between coins, the experts group has been suggesting that the half-euro coin be made with seven edges.
"The problem is that some parts of the vending machine industry, in particular some parts of the German industry, feel this could...introduce technical challenges," one official said.
Several EU countries, including Britain and Ireland, have multi-edged coins. Some try to differentiate between coins by putting holes in them or adding special surfaces.
Another glitch has occurred in the plans for the 10- and 20-cent euro coins.
Urged on by Sweden, the finance ministers have ordered the experts to consider reducing the nickel content of the coins on health grounds.
Officials in Stockholm have expressed concern about protecting people who are allergic to nickel.
The experts group had wanted to make the content of euro coins the same as for most existing world currencies in order to facilitate recycling.
